properties.areaDesc: Daviess, IN; Knox, IN; Gibson, IN; Pike, IN
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued January 9 at 2:03PM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
...The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a Flood
Warning for portions of the following waterways in central and
southern Indiana...

White River...Wabash River...

.Lowland flooding will develop along the White and Wabash rivers in western and central Indiana. Significant flooding along the Wabash River is likely. Flooding will affect some local and state roads...low agricultural land and some river
parks. Flooding will begin Saturday morning along the Wabash River and Sunday morning along the White River. A second system could prolong flooding along these rivers through next week.

A significant precipitation event will begin Thursday night and continue through Sunday Morning. Heaviest rainfall rates will be between Friday night and Saturday afternoon. Forecasted rainfall totals between 2 to 5 inches this weekend could cause flooding similar to floods along the Wabash River in June 2015 and floods along the White River in June 2019. Moderate flooding is expected along the Wabash River. Along the White River, minor to moderate flooding is expected.

The National Weather Service in Indianapolis has issued a

* Flood Warning for
the White River at Edwardsport.
* from Sunday afternoon until further notice.
* At  7:00 AM Thursday the stage was 10.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 15.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Sunday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 21.6 feet by late Tuesday night.
* At 22.9 feet...A 25 foot section of Levee Unit 8 failed at this
level on March 6 2011...flooding local roads behind the  levee.
Flooding not nearly as bad as June 2008 levee failure.  Flooding
was very close to one of the June 2008 failures.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
